_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Standard Hemp in 2019 purchased an existing Agricultural Cold Storage facility to dry and process Hemp. In 2021 the corporate name is changing to People's Farming, LLC. Staff and operation remains mainly the same. The facility originally had 2 separate mechanical rooms, Cold Storage buildings and refrigeration systems since they were used at different times of the year for different Agricultural products. Now both buildings are used for Hemp processing at the same time, so connecting the 2 smaller rooms to the main refrigeration system is more cost effective than updating the older equipment room. The Minor change is being done with an MOC process. All of the equipment in the older mechanical room will be disconnected permanently. There is plenty of capacity in the Main refrigeration system for the small addition. The NH3 refrigerant was transferred to the main system in March 2020 with demo and new piping to be completed in 90 days. The Worst Case and Alternate Case were not effected by eliminating the much smaller process. The Risk Management Program at People's Farming, LLC complies with US EPA and Cal ARP requirements.



The procedures for complying with the RM Program regulations are outlined by the following major steps:

1.    Identify Covered Processes

2.    Determine Program Level

3.    Establish a Management System

4.    Conduct a 5-year Accident History

5.    Perform Hazard Assessments

6.    Develop an Accident Prevention Program

7.    Develop an Emergency Response Program and

8.    Prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP)



Publication or sharing of OCA portions of RMP materials can be in violation of the Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act (PL106-40). 



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

We at People's Farming, LLC. are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  Our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating proc

edures, maintenance, and employee training demonstrates this commitment.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.





2.    The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Our facility's primary activities revolve around processing and storage of tree fruit.  This activity is consistent with SIC 0723/ NAICS 115114 post harvest crop activities. Anhydrous ammonia is the major regulated substance present at our facility.  The entire ammonia inventory is attributed to use as a refrigerant. Ammonia (anhydrous) is used as a refrigerant in a closed loop refrigeration system. 



3.    The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.



The worst-case release scenario mandated by the RMP Rule is a standardized hypothetical situation intended to promote "dialogue". According to the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration "The worst-case situation represents an extremely improbable (and for many facilities impossible) set of circumstances rather than a credible accident scenario. Release quantities and hazard distances derived there from for the worst-case scenario should not be used as a basis for emergency response planning."



To evaluate the worst case and alternative release scenarios for ammonia we have used the methodology given in the Model Risk Management Program and Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration by SAIC.  To perform the required offsite consequence analyses for other substances we have used.  Details are not provided in the Executive Summary. An alternate case scenario has also been evaluated and included. 





4.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 of the E

PA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Mechanical Code. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.



Process Safety Information

People's Farming, LLC. maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all the processes.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is What if /Checklist.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner and less than 2.5 years unless coordinated with the UPA.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, People's Farming, LLC. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.



Training

People's Farming, LLC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity

People's Farming, LLC carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, stora

ge tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are carried out by qualified personnel or Refrigeration Contractors with a strong background in maintenance practices.  Specialized training is provided to these personnel as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at People's Farming, LLC to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel and all other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change in a process are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the changes.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at People's Farming, LLC.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

People's Farming, LLC conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP Rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner. A new one is being done as requested by the UPA to reflect the new program documentation and systems.



Incident Investigation

People's Farming, LLC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. Any incidents that release a re-portable amount of

Ammonia require updating the 5 year Accident History and filing a revised RMP with the EPA.



Employee Participation

People's Farming, LLC truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information collected as part of the facility's compliance with the RMP Rule including information resulting from process hazard analyses.



 

Hot Work Permit

At People's Farming, LLC Hot Work Permit procedures are in place and enforced. Preventing accidents related to welding and cutting while alerting others at the facility that this type of work is occurring are important prevention steps.



Contractors

On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  People's Farming, LLC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response to an accidental release of a regulated substance.



5.    Five-year Accident History

People's Farming, LLC has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during this period at our previous Cold Storage facility. Any re-portable release requires updating the Accident History within 6 months.



6.    Emergency Action Plan

People's Farming, LLC has a written emergency action plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes steps for evaluation, health and safety, mitigation without entering a hazardous area, notification if emergency response is required, appropriate Clean-u

p and reporting. Any changes in Emergency Contact information is reported within 30 days.



7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. More frequent replacement of Safety Relief Valves, daily written logs of mechanical room inspections, updating emergency ventilation and connecting the smaller cold storage to the Main plant and removing the smaller separate refrigeration system.    These and other changes recommended at the last PHA re-validation should be implemented by 7/1/2022.
